awd_titl_txt: AF:   Small:   Collaborative Research:   A Robust Framework for Overcoming the Tangled Mesh Problem
awd_abstract_narration:
Engineers rely heavily on computer simulation to design and create products.  A critical part of computer simulation is mesh generation, where a virtual model of, say an aircraft landing-gear, is divided into a large number of simpler shapes, such as triangles, squares, and cubes. Unfortunately, for complex models, these simple shapes can get 'entangled' and overlap, which can lead to erroneous simulation results. This project will address this long-standing problem by developing: (1) new simulation methods that can work with a mildly tangled mesh, and (2) new methods of 'untangling' bad tangles. The project will have a significant impact on simulation in disciplines from biomechanics to manufacturing, and the team will create software for release to the scientific community. The PIs will create teaching modules to excite young students on the interconnectivity between meshes, scientific computing, and engineering.  Both universities will host outreach activities on computer simulation for K-12 students, including underrepresented minority students.

This project will develop a novel finite-cell simulation method to compute accurate results on tangled meshes that avoid certain types of explicit tangling. Therefore, in parallel, a new class of nonlinear optimization methods will be developed to handle tangling in quadrilateral, hexahedral, and high-order meshes that are significantly more difficult to untangle; the aim is to handle any input mesh by untangling until a numerically correct simulation can be guaranteed.  The viability of this unified and robust framework will be demonstrated through targeted applications.

por.por_cntn:
Meshes refer to the discretization of a geometry and serve as an approximation of the geometry for use with geometry-based analysis techniques.  The surface and volume of the geometry are typically discretized into shapes, e.g., triangles, quadrilaterals, pentagons, and hexagons in 2D, and tetrahedra, pyramids, prisms, and hexahedra in 3D.  

Meshes that contain inverted or overlapping elements are said to be tangled.  Tangled meshes lead to erroneous (i.e., non-physical results) in finite element simulations.  Finite element (FE) methods approximate the physics of an object by splitting it into a finite number of elements which are determined by the mesh elements.  Such methods numerically solve partial differential equations (PDEs) arising in the fields of structural analysis, fluid dynamics, and electromagnetics to name just a few.  Another issue with tangled meshes is that they lead to artifacts in texture mapping which is an important process in computer graphics.  There are several ways in which meshes can become tangled.  For example, meshes can become tangled during the mesh generation process, whereas others can become tangled when optimizing the positions of the nodes and/or elements in the mesh.  They can also become tangled when undergoing deformations, such as those that occur during dynamic simulations.  In this collaborative project, we sought to determine a robust solution to the tangled mesh problem. 

In this project, at the University of Kansas, we developed computer algorithms for untangling high-order triangular and tetrahedral meshes.  These meshes are typically tangled either during the mesh generation process or when undergoing a large deformation.  We also developed computer methods for generating high-order triangular and tetrahedral meshes and for warping them.  These methods provided us with several test cases of tangled meshes.  They also helped us to better understand the mechanism of tangling in high-order simplicial meshes.  We also developed a multiobjective optimization algorithm for untangling and mesh quality improvement of quadrilateral meshes.  The principle behind this method is to be able to combine multiple mesh optimization goals into a single problem to be solved efficiently.  In addition, we developed computer algorithms to generate meshes of parametric curves for use in computer graphics applications; these results could be extended to prevent mesh tangling.   We also developed a parallel variational mesh quality improvement method which is for use on a high performance computing cluster; it could also be extended to incorporate mesh untangling.  Finally, we developed computer tests for detecting edge tangling and degeneracy in high-order triangular meshes.  The algorithms will be shared with the scientific community for research and education purposes.  The results of the project were disseminated through research publications, a Ph.D. dissertation, conference presentations, and the organizing of minisymposia at conferences. 

Regarding education, we developed and taught a short course on moving meshes at the International Meshing Roundtable; students and researchers from universities, national laboratories, and companies from around the world attended the short course.  We have also begun development of an educational module on mesh optimization for senior undergraduate students in STEM fields.  This module will be used in a Design Optimization course taught by our collaborator at the University of Wisconsin - Madison.  The module will cover topics such as mesh quality improvement, mesh untangling, and mesh adaptivity.  An emphasis will be placed on practical applications of mesh optimization.    

We have organized several outreach activities focused on the middle school and high school levels to build pathways for women and underrepresented minorities.  One highlight was the high school summer camp at the University of Wisconsin - Madison which we taught on computer-aided engineering.  The students learned about CAD modeling and finite element analysis on unstructured meshes and completed individual projects.    At the University of Kansas, we organized a summer camp for middle school students which focused on computer modeling and 3D printing.  This camp focused on the basics of geometric design, computer-aided design modeling, meshing, finite element analysis, and 3D printing.

These research, education, and outreach activities were conducted at the University of Kansas by the research team and our collaborators from various institutions in the United States and abroad.

 


Last Modified: 12/13/2021
Modified by: Suzanne M Shontz

This camp focused on the basics of geometric design, computer-aided design modeling, meshing, finite element analysis, and 3D printing.

These research, education, and outreach activities were conducted at the University of Kansas by the research team and our collaborators from various institutions in the United States and abroad.
